contextId.information: Something very heavy that a person might carry is a metaphor for their many sins. AT: "their sin is like a heavy bag on their shoulders that makes it hard for them to walk" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: a people weighed down with iniquity

contextId.information: This metaphor compares the punishment God has given Israel to physical wounds. It can be stated in active form. AT: "no one has closed, cleansed, bandaged, or treated them with oil" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: they have not been closed, cleansed, bandaged, nor treated with oil

contextId.information: Here God compares a person who stops sinning with one who washes his body. AT: "Repent and wash the sin from your heart like you wash the dirt from your body" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Wash, cleanse yourselves

contextId.information: God speaks of people who oppress others as if they had made crooked something that should be straight, and he calls on them to make that object straight again. The abstract noun "oppression" can be translated as a verb. AT: "make sure that those helpless people you have harmed no longer suffer from the bad things you have done to them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
contextId.quote: make straight the oppression

contextId.information: Isaiah compared the people to a woman who is not loyal to her husband but who sleeps with other men for money. The people were no longer loyal to God but were worshiping false gods. AT: "acts like a prostitute" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: has become a prostitute

contextId.information: The word "she" refers to Jerusalem and its people. Those who wrote the Bible often refer to cities as women. AT: "but now the people of Jerusalem are murderers" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: but now she is full of murderers

contextId.information: Possible meanings are that Isaiah uses silver and wine as metaphors for 1) the people of Jerusalem. AT: "You are like silver that is no longer pure, and like wine that is mixed with water," or 2) the good deeds that the people formerly did. AT: "You used to do good deeds, but now your bad deeds make your good deeds worthless." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Your silver has become impure, your wine mixed with water

contextId.information: Isaiah speaks of honor in metaphor as if it were physical height. This can be stated 1) in active form. AT: "Yahweh will honor it more than any other hill" or 2) as a metonym for the people who worship there. AT: "Yahweh will honor the people who worship there more than he honors any other people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: it will be raised up above the hills

contextId.information: The people around the world going to the mountain of Yahweh is compared to how a river flows. This emphasizes that many people will come, not just a few people. AT: "will flow like a river to it" or "will go to it" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: will flow to it

contextId.information: "For the law will go out from Zion." Isaiah speaks as if the law were something like a river that moves without people doing anything. AT: "Those to whom they teach the law will go out from Zion" or "Yahweh will proclaim his law from Zion" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: For out of Zion will go the law

contextId.information: "the word of Yahweh will go out from Jerusalem." Isaiah speaks as if the word of Yahweh were something like a river that moves without people doing anything. You can make clear the understood information. AT: "Those to whom they teach the word of Yahweh will go out from Jerusalem" or "Yahweh will proclaim his word from Jerusalem" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]])
contextId.quote: the word of Yahweh from Jerusalem

contextId.information: Isaiah speaks of people learning and then doing what Yahweh wants them to do as if they were walking at night with a lamp that Yahweh has provided so they can see the path. AT: "let us learn how Yahweh wants us to live and then live that way" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: let us walk in the light of Yahweh

contextId.information: Isaiah speaks as if the land were a container in which someone had placed silver, horses, and idols. The word "land" is a metonym for the people themselves, and the words "is full of" is a metaphor for the people possessing these items. AT: "They possess much silver ... they also possess many horses ... They also possess many idols" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: Their land is full of silver ... their land also is full of horses ... Their land also is full of idols

contextId.information: Here being low to the ground represents people who are completely humiliated because they realize all they trusted in is worthless, and they can do nothing to help themselves. This can be stated in active form. AT: "God will make the people ashamed, and they will realize that all they trusted in is worthless" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: The people will be bowed down, and individuals will fall down

contextId.information: The words "raise them up" are a metaphor for Yahweh forgiving the people. AT: "do not forgive them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: do not raise them up

contextId.information: "Yahweh will bring down the lofty gaze of man." A man with a "lofty gaze" is looking above everyone to show them that he is better than they are. Here all people are guilty of thinking they are better than Yahweh, and the way they look at those who worship Yahweh, is a metonym for their pride. AT: "Yahweh will make ashamed all people because they think they are better than he is" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: The lofty gaze of man will be brought low

contextId.information: The "day of Yahweh of Hosts" will be against the cedars and oaks. Possible meanings are 1) these trees are a metaphor for the proud people whom God will judge or 2) God will actually destroy these mighty trees. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: against all the cedars of Lebanon ... against all the oaks of Bashan

contextId.information: These words are metaphors for the pride of the Israelites. They also appear in [[:en:bible:notes:isa:02:01|2:2]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: mountains ... hills

contextId.information: These refer to things people would build around their cities so they could defend themselves against their enemies. They are a metaphor for the Israelites' pride and belief that they had no need for Yahweh and could stand against any punishment Yahweh would mete out to them for their sins. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: high tower ... impregnable wall

contextId.information: Disobeying God is spoken of as if it were stumbling and falling. (See:   [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Jerusalem has stumbled, and Judah has fallen

contextId.information: Isaiah speaks of Yahweh's decision to harm the people as if Yahweh were bringing a legal accusation in a courtroom against the people of Israel. The second part of this line means the same thing as the first part, but it says it a little more completely. AT: "It is as though Yahweh had taken his place in a courtroom and were ready to accuse the people" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
contextId.quote: Yahweh stands up for an accusation; he is standing to accuse the people

contextId.information: Making people suffer is spoken of as if it were rubbing their faces into the ground. AT: "harm the poor and make them suffer" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: grind the faces of the poor

contextId.information: Zion, meaning here the city of Jerusalem, is spoken of as if it were a woman with her daughters. AT: "the women of Zion" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: the daughters of Zion

contextId.information: "Fruit" sometimes simply represents food produced in the land, and sometimes it represents spiritual blessings. Possible meanings here are 1) God will cause the land to produce good food again. AT: "the people who are still in Israel will enjoy the best food from the land" or 2) the future Messiah will bring spiritual blessings to the people in the land. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: the fruit of the land will be tasty and delightful for those survivors in Israel

contextId.information: Possible meanings are 1) this is a metaphor that means Yahweh will remove sinners from Zion like a fire removes impurities or 2) "flaming fire" is a metonym that represents the destruction in general of all the sinners. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: the spirit of flaming fire

contextId.information: This phrase speaks of Sheol, which stands here for the grave, to an animal that is ready to eat other animals. It implies that many, many people will die. AT: "death is like a hungry animal that has opened its mouth wide to eat up many people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Sheol has made its appetite greater and has opened its mouth very wide

contextId.information: Being honored is spoken of as if it were being lifted high. AT: "will be greatly honored" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: will be exalted

contextId.information: Isaiah speaks of Yahweh's anger as if it were a fire. AT: "Yahweh is very angry" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: the anger of Yahweh is kindled

contextId.information: The people who will serve Yahweh after armies destroy Israel are spoken of as if they were set apart as a holy seed. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: the holy seed

contextId.information: God compares Rezin and Pekah to burning sticks whose fire has gone out and are making smoke now. God is emphasizing that they are not real threats to Judah. This can be stated in active form. AT: "do not let Rezin and Pekah make you afraid; their fierce anger is like a burning stick whose fire has gone out and there is only smoke" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: do not be afraid or intimidated by these two smoldering firebrands, by the fierce anger of Rezin and Aram, and of Pekah son of Remaliah

contextId.information: The words "gentle waters" are a metaphor for the law of the Lord. AT: "Because this people has rejected Yahweh's law, which is like the gentle waters of Shiloah" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
contextId.quote: Because this people has refused the gentle waters of Shiloah

contextId.information: The river symbolizes the army of Assyria. AT: "the army from Assyria, which is powerful like a mighty river" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: the waters of the River, mighty and many, the king of Assyria and all his glory

contextId.information: The army of Assyria is like a flood of water. AT: "More and more soldiers will come like a river rising up to your neck" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: The River will sweep onward into Judah, flooding and passing on, until it reaches to your neck

contextId.information: Isaiah speaks of people who do not know God as if they were people walking in darkness without any light. AT: "it is because they are like a person lost in the dark" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: it is because they have no light of dawn

contextId.information: Isaiah speaks of people who are spiritually lost as if they were walking around in total darkness. This can be stated in active form. AT: "Yahweh will remove the darkness from her who was in anguish" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: The gloom will be dispelled from her who was in anguish

contextId.information: "her who was suffering great pain and sadness." This is probably a metaphor for the people of Judah (see UDB). (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: her who was in anguish

contextId.information: Isaiah speaks of the people living sinful lives and suffering because of it as if they had been walking in a dark or living in a land of shadow of death. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: walked in darkness ... lived in the land of the shadow of death

contextId.information: Isaiah speaks of the Israelites, who are the Assyrians' slaves, as if they were an ox wearing a yoke. This will happen in the future, but he speaks as if it has already happened. AT: "For as on the day of Midian you will set the people of Israel free from being slaves to their oppressors like a person removes a yoke from the shoulders of an animal" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_pastforfuture]])
contextId.quote: For the yoke of his burden ... you have shattered as on the day of Midian

contextId.information: Isaiah speaks as if Yahweh were a person about to hit another person with his fist. This is a metaphor for Yahweh punishing Israel. Translate as in [[:en:bible:notes:isa:05:25|5:25]]. AT: "he will still be ready to punish them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: his hand is still stretched out

contextId.information: Isaiah explains this metaphor in verse 15. The "head," the part of an animal a person would want to be, is "the leader and the noble man," and the "tail," the dirty part of the animal, is "the prophet who teaches lies." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: head and tail

contextId.information: The leaders causing people to disobey is spoken of as if the leaders led them on the wrong path. AT: "The leaders of Israel have caused the people to disobey God" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Those who lead this people lead them astray

contextId.information: Isaiah speaks as if Yahweh were a person about to hit another person with his fist. This is a metaphor for Yahweh punishing Israel. Translate as in [[:en:bible:notes:isa:05:25|5:25]]. AT: "he will still be ready to punish them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: his hand is still stretched out

contextId.information: Yahweh speaks of his wrath as if it were more liquid than a container could hold; "the people" are trying to carry this container, but it is heavy, and Yahweh keeps pouring liquid in even after it starts to spill out. AT: "at whom I continue to be angry even after I have punished them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: who bear my overflowing wrath

contextId.information: Possible meanings are 1) the king of Assyria has shamed the people of the countries he conquered (see UDB) or 2) he has removed the kings of the nations so they no longer rule. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I have brought down the inhabitants

contextId.information: The phrase "light of Israel" refers to Yahweh. It is unclear whether Yahweh or Isaiah is speaking. AT: "I, Yahweh, the light of Israel, will become like a fire" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: The light of Israel will become a fire

contextId.information: Possible meaning are 1) "Yahweh will destroy the great forests and farmlands in the nation of Assyria" or 2) "Yahweh will destroy the army of Assyria as a fire burns up great forests and farmlands." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Yahweh will consume the glory of his forest and of his fruitful land

contextId.information: "will beat the Assyrians with a whip." God will not really use a whip. This refers to God's power to punish the Assyrians severely. AT: "will punish the Assyrians severely as if with a whip" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: will wield a whip against them

contextId.information: This expression suggests that the neck of the animal that is wearing the yoke will become too fat to fit the yoke any longer. This is a metaphor for Israel becoming so strong that the Assyrians can no longer rule them. This can be stated in active form. AT: "your neck will become so fat that it will break the yoke" or "you will become so strong that you will no longer be the Assyrians' slaves" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: the yoke will be destroyed because of fatness

contextId.information: Isaiah speaks of the army of Assyria as if it were the tall trees in Lebanon. God will destroy the army like people cutting down the mighty trees of Lebanon. This emphasizes that though the army is strong, God has the power to destroy it. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: will lop off the boughs ... and Lebanon in his majesty will fall

contextId.information: "the dense shrubs in the forest." This is possibly a metaphor for those people who are not well known. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: the thickets of the forest

contextId.information: "the forests of Lebanon will no longer be so grand." This is possibly a metaphor for the Assyrian army. AT: "Yahweh will defeat the army of Assyria, as mighty as it is" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Lebanon in his majesty will fall

contextId.information: Resting upon him represents being with him and helping him. The word "him" refers to the one who would become king. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: The Spirit of Yahweh will rest upon him

contextId.information: Wearing righteousness like a belt represents being righteous. Possible meanings are 1) the king's righteousness will enable him to rule. AT: "His righteousness will be a like a belt around his waist" or 2) the king's righteousness would show his authority to rule. AT: "He will rule righteously" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Righteousness will be the belt of his waist

contextId.information: Wearing faithfulness like a belt represents being faithful. Possible meanings are 1) the king's faithfulness will enable him to rule, or 2) the king's faithfulness will show his authority to rule. AT: "his faithfulness will be a like a belt around his hips" or "he will rule faithfully"  (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: faithfulness the belt around his hips

contextId.information: Possible meanings are 1) "The Lord will set up the king as a banner for the nations" or 2) "The king will set up a banner for the nations" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: He will set up a banner for the nations

contextId.information: The people of Israel and Judah are  pictured as if they were birds that fly down quickly to attack a person or animal. AT: "they will go quickly to the Philistine hills to attack the people there" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: they will swoop down on the Philistine hills

contextId.information: God causing someone's salvation is spoken of as if God were that salvation. The abstract noun "salvation" can be expressed with the noun "savior" or the verb "save". AT: "God causes my salvation" or "God is my savior" or "God is the one who saves me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
contextId.quote: God is my salvation

contextId.information: Isaiah speaks of people being saved as if they were getting salvation the way people get water out of well. AT: "you will rejoice when he saves you, as people rejoice when they draw water from a well" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: With joy you will draw water from the wells of salvation

contextId.information: Something that is about to happen soon is spoken of as if it is coming near. AT: "the day of Yahweh will happen soon" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: the day of Yahweh is near

contextId.information: The word "it" refers to the day of Yahweh. "It comes with destruction" means that destruction will happen on that day. "Destruction from the Almighty" means that the Almighty will destroy them. AT: "on that day, the Almighty God will destroy them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
contextId.quote: it comes with destruction from the Almighty

contextId.information: People being terribly afraid is spoken of as if their hearts melt. AT: "everyone is terribly afraid" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: every heart melts

contextId.information: The day coming with wrath and anger means that there will be wrath and anger on that day. The abstract nouns "wrath" and "anger" can be expressed with the adjectives "furious" and "angry". AT: "on the day of Yahweh, he will be furious and extremely angry" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: the day of Yahweh comes with cruel wrath and overflowing anger

contextId.information: Being low often represents being humble. Bringing down people's arrogance represents making them humble. AT: "and will humble the ruthless" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: and will bring down the arrogance of the ruthless

contextId.information: Making people want to do something is spoken of as stirring them up. AT: "I am about to make the Medes want to attack them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I am about to stir up the Medes to attack them

contextId.information: The daystar is a bright star that rises just before morning. The people of Israel will refer to the king of Babylon in terms of this star in order to imply that he once was great, but now he was not. AT: "You were like the bright morning star, but you have fallen from the sky" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: How you are fallen from heaven, daystar, son of the morning

contextId.information: The word "them" refers to the other kings who died and were buried properly. Joining them in burial represents being buried as they were. AT: "you will never be buried as other kings were buried" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: You will not join them in burial

contextId.information: This represents wild animals living in the city because there are no people there. AT: "a place where owls live" or "a place where wild animals live" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: a possession of owls

contextId.information: God being ready to punish the nations is spoken of as if he raised his hand in order to hit them. The word "hand" may also represent his power. AT: "and this is Yahweh's power to punish all the nations" or "this is how Yahweh will punish the nations" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: and this is the hand that is raised over all the nations

contextId.information: This represents Yahweh being ready to punish the nations. AT: "He is ready to punish them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: His hand is raised

contextId.information: The rod that struck Philistia represents a king who sent his army to attack them. Being broken represents either being dead or being defeated. AT: "the king that sent his army against you is dead" or "the army that attacked you is defeated" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: the rod that struck you is broken

contextId.information: Here the word "fiery" probably refers to the serpent's poisonous bite, and the word "flying" refers to its quick movements. AT: "a quickly moving poisonous snake" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: a fiery flying serpent

contextId.information: People's crying out and others hearing it is spoken of as if the cry had gone out. AT: "People all over the territory of Moab cry out"  (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: The cry has gone around the territory of Moab

contextId.information: The heat of the middle of the day represents the Moabites' suffering from their enemies, and shade represents protection from their enemies. Comparing the shade to night shows that they want strong protection. AT: "protect us completely from our enemies as a large shadow protects people from the hot sun" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: provide some shade like night in the middle of the day

contextId.information: The word "Gleanings" here represents the people who will still live in Israel. AT: "But there will be a few people left in Israel" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Gleanings will be left

contextId.information: Being crushed represents being discouraged. AT: "will be discouraged" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: will be crushed

contextId.information: The princes of Zoan and Memphis are spoken of as if they are the cornerstones of buildings because they are an important part of the community. AT: "the leaders have made Egypt go astray"  (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: they have made Egypt go astray, who are the cornerstones of her tribes

contextId.information: Isaiah speaks of Yahweh's judgment as if Egypt was a cup of wine. He speaks of Yahweh causing the leaders' thoughts to be distorted as if their distorted thoughts were a liquid that Yahweh mixed in with the wine. AT: "Yahweh has judged them by distorting their thoughts" or "Yahweh has judged Egypt by distorting its leaders' thoughts, as intoxicating drinks confuse people's thoughts" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Yahweh has mixed a spirit of distortion into her midst

contextId.information: The "head," the part of an animal a person would want to be, represents the leader. The "tail" is the opposite and represents people who follow. AT: "whether leader or follower" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: whether head or tail

contextId.information: The "palm branch" grows high on the tree and represents people who are wealthy and important. The "reed" grows in shallow water and represents people who are poor and unimportant. See how you translated similar phrases in [[:en:bible:notes:isa:09:13|9:14]]. AT: "whether they are important or unimportant" or "whether rich or poor" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: palm branch or reed

contextId.information: The enemy soldiers coming and taking Shebna as a captive to a foreign land is spoken of as if Yahweh were throwing him like a ball into another land. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: He will surely wind you round and round, and toss you like a ball into a vast country

contextId.information: Yahweh causing Shebna to no longer work in the king's palace is spoken of as if Yahweh will throw him to the ground. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I will thrust you from your office and from your station. You will be pulled down

contextId.information: Yahweh causing Eliakim's authority to be strong and secure in the king's palace is spoken of as if Eliakim were a peg and Yahweh will set him firmly in the palace wall. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I will fasten him, a peg in a secure place

contextId.information: Yahweh causing Eliakim's whole family to be honored because of Eliakim is spoken of as if Eliakim were a peg in the wall and his family were something that hangs on the peg. AT: "They will give honor to his whole family because of him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: They will hang on him all the glory of his father's house

contextId.information: Yahweh causing Shebna to lose his authority in the king's palace is spoken of as if Shebna were a peg in the wall that breaks off and falls to the ground. This emphasizes that Shebna thought his authority was secure but God will remove him. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: the peg driven in a firm place ... will be cut off

contextId.information: Here "weight" represents Shebna's power and authority. It is spoken of as if it were an object hanging on the peg that represents Shebna. Yahweh causing Shebna to lose his power and authority is spoken of as if someone were to cut off the object that was hanging on the peg. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: the weight that was on it will be cut off

contextId.information: This speaks about the people of Tyre as if they were a prostitute. Just as a prostitute who is no longer popular may sing in the streets to regain her former lovers, the people of Tyre will try to get people from other nations to return to them to continue trading so that the people of Tyre will be rich and powerful again. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: like in the song of the prostitute ... so that you may be remembered

contextId.information: Isaiah compares the people of Tyre with a prostitute. Just as the prostitute sells herself for money to any man, the people of Tyre will again buy and sell to all kingdoms. AT: "And like a prostitute they will buy and sell will all the kingdoms of the earth" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: she will start making money again by doing the work of a prostitute ... of the earth

contextId.information: The people sinning and making the earth unacceptable to God is spoken of as if the people made the earth physically unclean. This can be stated in active form. AT: "The people have polluted the earth" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: The earth is polluted by its inhabitants

contextId.information: This speaks of large amounts of rain falling from the sky as if Yahweh opened a window in the sky and let the water pour through. AT: "The sky will split open and torrents of rain will fall" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: The windows of the heavens will be opened

contextId.information: Yahweh protecting his people is spoken of as if he were a place that the people could go to be safe and comforted. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: you have been a place of safety ... a shelter ... a shelter from the storm ... a shade from the heat

contextId.information: Yahweh causing the people to never be ashamed again is spoken of as if disgrace were an object that Yahweh would take away. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: the disgrace of his people he will take away from all the earth

contextId.information: Yahweh having the power to protect his people is spoken of as if he were a tall rock where people could go to escape from their enemies. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Yahweh, is an everlasting rock

contextId.information: Yahweh humiliating those who are proud is spoken of as if proud people were up high and he would cause them to come down low. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: he will bring down those who live proudly

contextId.information: Yahweh preparing to punish wicked people is spoken of as if his hand were raised and about to hit the wicked people. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: your hand is lifted up

contextId.information: This speaks of dead people coming back to life as if they were waking up from sleep. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Awake

contextId.information: "Sing about the vineyard of wine." This speaks about the people of Israel as if they were a vineyard that produced fruit. AT: "Sing about the people of Israel as if they were a vineyard that produced grapes for wine" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: A vineyard of wine, sing of it

contextId.information: This speaks about a day as if it travels and arrives somewhere. AT: "In the future" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: In the coming day

contextId.information: Yahweh blessing the people of Israel and causing them to prosper is spoken of as if they were a vine that grows roots and blossoms. AT: "the descendants of Israel will prosper like a vine that has taken root and blossomed" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Jacob will take root; Israel will blossom and bud

contextId.information: Yahweh's power to send his people away to a foreign country is spoken of as if Yahweh used a wind to blow them to a foreign country. AT: "the power of Yahweh drove them out like a severe wind from the east" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: he drove them away with his severe wind, on the day of the east wind

contextId.information: This speaks of the results of an action as if it were the fruit that grows as on a tree or vine. AT: "the result" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: the full fruit

contextId.information: A "garland" is a crown made of flowers. Here it represents the city of Samaria, the capital of Israel, which sits above a fertile valley. Samaria and its people being destroyed is spoken of as if the flowers in the garland will grow old and stop being beautiful. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Woe to the proud garland ... on the head of the lush Valley of those who are overcome with wine

contextId.information: Yahweh is spoken of as if he were to become a beautiful crown that the people who honor him as their true king would wear. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: will become a beautiful crown and a diadem of beauty

contextId.information: The enemy soldiers capturing the people of Israel is spoken of as if they were hunters that catch an animal in a snare. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: ensnared

contextId.information: Yahweh testing according to his justice and righteousness to determine if the people are just and righteous is spoken of as if he were a builder using tools to determine that something is the correct length and perfectly level. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I will make justice the measuring stick, and righteousness the plumbline

contextId.information: Possible meanings are 1) the leaders of Jerusalem had used magic or sorcery to try to make an agreement with the gods of the place of the dead so that these gods would protect them from dying or 2) this is a metaphor that speaks of the leaders having made an agreement with the leaders of Egypt. The leaders of Jerusalem were so confident that the Egyptians would protect that it was like they had made an agreement with the gods of the place of the dead. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:isa:28:14|28:15]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: covenant with death ... agreement with Sheol

contextId.information: Yahweh punishing the people even more severely is spoken of as if he would tighten their bonds. This can be stated in active form. AT: "Yahweh will tighten your bonds" or "Yahweh will punish you even more severely" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: your bonds will be tightened

contextId.information: Here "the spirit of" means "to have the characteristic of" being asleep. Yahweh causing the people to be asleep is spoken of as if "the spirit" were a liquid that he poured out on the people. Also "deep sleep" is a metaphor that means the people are senseless and cannot understand what Yahweh is doing. AT: "The reason you are senseless is because Yahweh has caused you to be spiritually asleep" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: For Yahweh has poured out on you the spirit of deep sleep

contextId.information: People trying to make plans without Yahweh knowing about it is spoken of as if they hide their plans in a deep place where Yahweh cannot see. AT: "who try to hide their plans from Yahweh" or "who try to keep Yahweh from finding out what they are planning to do" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: who deeply hide their plans from Yahweh

contextId.information: Yahweh speaks about his people as if they were his children. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: the rebellious children

contextId.information: Continuing to sin is spoken of as if sins were objects that could be stacked on one another. AT: "they continue to sin more and more" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: they add sin to sin

contextId.information: Here "it" refers to the part in the wall that is about to fall. The part in the wall is a metaphor that represents the people of Judah and their sin mentioned in [[:en:bible:notes:isa:30:12|30:12-13]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: He will break it

contextId.information: Yahweh being extremely angry is spoken of as if he were a large fire. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: the name of Yahweh ... like a devouring fire

contextId.information: Yahweh causing an army to defeat the Assyrians is spoken of as if Yahweh would hit the Assyrians with a rod. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Every stroke of the appointed rod that Yahweh will lay on them

contextId.information: This speaks about people relying on their horses to help them as if they were leaning on their horses. AT: "rely on their horses" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: lean on horses

contextId.information: The phrase "retract his words" speaks of a person not fulfilling what they said they will do as if the words that he had said were something that he could pull back to himself. Here it says that Yahweh will not do this, meaning he will fulfill what he has said. AT: "he will do what he said he would do" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: will not retract his words

contextId.information: This speaks of Yahweh giving him Spirit to his people as if his Spirit were a liquid that he would pour on them. AT: "the Spirit is given to us" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: the Spirit is poured on us

contextId.information: This speaks of Yahweh ruling Zion with his justice and righteousness as if he were filling Zion with justice and righteousness. AT: "He will rule Zion with justice and righteousness" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: He will fill Zion with justice and righteousness

contextId.information: Possible meanings: 1) The Assyrian army is like a boat that is unable to move through the water: the ropes that support the mast and sail have come loose and no longer support the mast, so the sail is useless ([[:en:bible:notes:isa:33:01|33:01]]) or 2) the people of Judah are no longer at war: "You have loosened the cords that supported your flagpole; the flag no longer flies" ([[:en:bible:notes:isa:33:17|33:17]]-[[:en:bible:notes:isa:33:22|22]], see UDB). (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Your riggings are slack; they cannot hold the mast in place; they cannot spread the sail

contextId.information: Yahweh describes himself as a warrior bearing a sword. The phrase "drunk its fill" speaks of Yahweh's sword as if it were a person who has eaten and become satisfied. Yahweh uses this imagery to emphasize that there will be a lot of destruction in heaven and to state its completion. AT: "when I am finished destroying things in heaven" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
contextId.quote: when my sword will have drunk its fill in heaven

contextId.information: This speaks of Yahweh killing the people as if he were a priest sacrificing animals. He does this by describing the sword of a priest. AT: "Yahweh sacrifices them as a priest sacrifices animals, whose sword drips with the blood and fat of lambs, goats, and rams" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: The sword of Yahweh is dripping with blood and covered with fat ... of rams

contextId.information: The water and land becoming useless for drinking or growing food because it is burnt and covered in pitch and sulfur is spoken of as if their streams and land will actually become pitch and sulfur. AT: "The streams in Edom will be full of pitch and the ground will be covered with burning sulfur and burning pitch" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: The streams of Edom will be turned into pitch ... become burning pitch

contextId.information: This speaks of Yahweh deciding where to cause the animals to live as if he actually cast lots for their places. AT: "He has determined where they will live" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: He has cast lots for their places

contextId.information: This speaks of Egypt, specifically its army and its Pharaoh, as if it were a splintered reed to emphasize that relying on them would not help them but would only harm them. AT: "that is like walking with a splintered reed for a staff. If a man leans on it, it will stick into his hand and pierce it" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: that splintered reed that you use as a walking staff, but if a man leans on it, it will stick into his hand and pierce it

contextId.information: This refers to speaking loudly as if the person's voice were an object that they lifted high. AT: "have you shouted" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: have you exalted your voice

contextId.information: This speaks of Yahweh hearing the king's speech as if the king's speech were something that traveled to his ear. AT: "I have heard you speaking arrogantly" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: your arrogance has reached my ears

contextId.information: This speaks of the people of Judah becoming prosperous as if they were plants that would root and bear fruit. AT: "will prosper like a plant that takes root and produces fruit" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: will again take root and bear fruit

contextId.information: The speaker speaks of humans as if they are grass, because they both die quickly. AT: "people die as quickly as grass" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: humanity is grass

contextId.information: The writer speaks of Yahweh's people as if they were sheep and of Yahweh as if he were their shepherd. AT: "He will care for his people like a shepherd feeds his flock" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: He will feed his flock like a shepherd

contextId.information: A "span" is the measure of length between the thumb and little finger when the hand is outstretched. Yahweh knowing the length of the sky is spoken of as if he measured it with his hand. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: measured the sky with the span of his hand

contextId.information: The prophet speaks of rulers being helpless before Yahweh as if they were new plants that wither away when a hot wind blows on them. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: they are barely planted ... and they wither

contextId.information: People receiving strength from Yahweh is spoken of as if the people were able to fly like eagles fly. An eagle is a bird often used as a symbol for strength and power. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: they will soar with wings like eagles

contextId.information: Possible meanings are 1) this is a metaphor in which he and his army moving very quickly is spoken of as if his feet barely touch the ground. AT: "by a path on which he moves with great speed" or 2) "feet" is a synecdoche and the phrase indicates that this is a path that they have not traveled before. AT: "by a path that he has never traveled before" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: by a swift path that his feet scarcely touch

contextId.information: The places on the earth that are very far away are spoken of as if they were the places where the earth ends. AT "the farthest places of the earth" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: the ends of the earth

contextId.information: The places on the earth that are very far away are spoken of as if they were the places where the earth ends. Translate this in the same way you translated it in [[:en:bible:notes:isa:41:05|41:5]]. AT "the farthest places of the earth" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: the ends of the earth

contextId.information: Yahweh helping the people of Israel is spoken of as if he were holding their right hand. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I ... will hold your right hand

contextId.information: Possible meanings are 1) that this refers to the opinions of other nations regarding the people of Israel or 2) that this refers to Israel's own opinion of themselves. Yahweh speaks of their insignificance as if they were a worm. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Jacob you worm

contextId.information: Yahweh speaks of enabling Israel to defeat their enemies as if he were making the nation a threshing sledge that will level mountains. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I am making you like a sharp threshing sledge ... you will make the hills like chaff

contextId.information: Here the word "them" refers to the mountains and hill in [[:en:bible:notes:isa:41:14|41:15]]. This represents the next step in the process of threshing grain, in which the grain is winnowed to get rid of the chaff. Israel's enemies will disappear like chaff blown away by the wind. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: You will winnow them ... the wind will scatter them

contextId.information: Yahweh speaks of appointing a person as if he raised that person up. AT: "I have appointed one" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I have raised up one

contextId.information: Yahweh speaks of weak and helpless people as if they were crushed reeds and dimly burning wicks. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: A crushed reed he will not break, and a dimly burning wick he will not quench

contextId.information: Causing blind people to see is spoken of as if it were opening their eyes. Also, Yahweh speaks of his servant delivering those who have been wrongly imprisoned as if his servant were restoring sight to blind people. AT: "to enable the blind to see" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: to open the eyes of the blind

contextId.information: Here "zeal" refers to the passion that a warrior experiences when he is about to fight a battle. Yahweh stimulating his zeal is spoken of as if he stirred it up like the wind stirs up waves of water. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: he will stir up his zeal

contextId.information: Yahweh uses this metaphorical language to describe his great power to conquer his enemies. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I will lay waste mountains ... will dry up the marshes

contextId.information: Rejecting those who worship idols is spoken of as if it is forcing them to turn back and move the opposite direction. This can be stated in active form. AT: "I will reject them and put them to shame" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: They will be turned back, they will be completely put to shame

contextId.information: Isaiah speaks of Yahweh's anger as if it were a liquid that could be poured out. AT: "he demonstrated his fierce anger towards them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: he poured out his fierce anger against them

contextId.information: Yahweh speaks of suffering and difficult experiences as if they are deep waters and fires through which the people walk. The words "waters" and "flames" form a merism and emphasize any difficult circumstance. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_merism]])
contextId.quote: When you pass through the waters ... the flames will not destroy you

contextId.information: Yahweh speaks of those who do not listen to him or obey him as if they were blind and deaf. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: the people who are blind ... the deaf

contextId.information: Forgiving sins is spoken of as either 1) blotting them out or wiping them away or 2) erasing a written record of the sins. AT: "who forgives your offenses like someone wiping something away" or "who forgives your offenses like someone who erases a record of sins" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: who blots out your offenses

contextId.information: Yahweh speaks of creating the nation of Israel as if it were forming the nation as a baby in its mother's womb. AT: "he who made you, as I form a baby in the womb" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: he who made you and formed you in the womb

contextId.information: Yahweh speaks of giving his Spirit to the people of Israel as if he were causing rain to fall and streams to flow on dry ground. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I will pour water on the thirsty ground, and flowing streams on the dry ground

contextId.information: The people of Israel being prosperous and multiplying is spoken of as if they were plants that grow because they have plenty of water. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: They will spring up among the grass, like willows by the streams of water

contextId.information: Yahweh speaks of those who cannot understand the foolishness of worshiping idols as if they were blind. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: for their eyes are blind and cannot see

contextId.information: Yahweh speaks of creating the nation of Israel as if it were forming the nation as a baby in its mother's womb. See how you translated a similar phrase in [[:en:bible:notes:isa:44:01|44:2]]. AT: "he who made you, as I form a baby in the womb" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: he who formed you from the womb

contextId.information: Yahweh speaks of Cyrus ruling and protecting the people of Israel as if Cyrus is their shepherd. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: He is my shepherd

contextId.information: Yahweh helping Cyrus and causing him to be successful is spoken of as if he were holding his right hand. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: whose right hand I hold

contextId.information: Yahweh speaks of removing obstacles that would hinder Cyrus's success as if it were leveling mountains before him. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: and level the mountains

contextId.information: Yahweh speaks of his righteousness as if it were rain that falls on the earth, and of his righteousness and salvation as plants that grow on the earth. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: You heavens, rain down from above ... righteousness spring up together with it

contextId.information: Yahweh speaks of himself as if he were a potter, and of the one who would argue with him as if that person and the rest of humanity were all clay pots. AT: "like one piece of pottery among many other pieces of pottery scattered on the ground" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: any other earthen pot among all the earthen pots in the ground

contextId.information: Yahweh speaks of causing Cyrus to act as if it were stirring him from slumber. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I stirred Cyrus

contextId.information: Yahweh speaks of removing obstacles and causing Cyrus to be successful as if he were making the paths smooth on which Cyrus walks. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I will smooth out all his paths

contextId.information: The places on the earth that are very far away are spoken of as if they were the places where the earth ends. This phrase also forms a merism and refers to everywhere in between the ends. AT "all the farthest places of the earth" or "the entire earth" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_merism]])
contextId.quote: all the ends of the earth

contextId.information: Isaiah speaks of people placing the idols of Bel and Nebo into a cart for animals to transport as if these gods were made to "bow down" and "stoop." These are both postures of humiliation. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Bel bows down, Nebo stoops; their idols ... for weary animals

contextId.information: Yahweh speaks of the people stubbornly doing wrong as if they were physically far away from doing the right thing. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: who are far from doing what is right

contextId.information: Yahweh speaks of the people of Israel being his special possession as if they were his heritage or inheritance. AT: "I defiled my people, who are my special possession" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I defiled my heritage

contextId.information: Yahweh speaks of the Babylonians oppressing the old people as if they had treated the old people like cattle and put heavy yokes on their necks. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: you placed a very heavy yoke on the old people

contextId.information: Yahweh speaks of explaining something as if it were unfolding it. The word "ears" represents the people who are listening. This can be stated in active form. AT: "I did not explain these things to you beforehand" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]],  [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]], and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: these things were not unfolded to your ears beforehand

contextId.information: Yahweh speaks of using affliction to purify his people as if they were precious metals and affliction were a furnace in which he refines them. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Look, I refined you, but not as silver; I have purified you in the furnace of affliction

contextId.information: Yahweh speaks of creating the heavens as if they were fabric which Yahweh stretched out. See how you translated a similar phrase in [[:en:bible:notes:isa:42:05|42:5]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: spread out the heavens

contextId.information: Yahweh teaching the people how they should live is spoken of as if he were leading them to walk on the correct paths. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: who leads you by the way that you should go

contextId.information: God giving the servant strength is spoken of as if God himself were his strength. AT: "my God has given me strength" or "my God has strengthened me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: my God has become my strength

contextId.information: Yahweh speaks of the land as if it were an inheritance that the people of Israel received as a permanent possession. It is implied that the servant is to reassign the land to the people of Israel. AT: "to reassign the desolate land to the people of Israel as their inheritance" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: to reassign the desolate inheritance

contextId.information: Yahweh speaks of his unwavering devotion to Zion as if he had written her name on the palms of his hands. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I have inscribed your name on my palms

contextId.information: Yahweh speaks of always thinking about Zion as if her walls were always before him. The word "walls" is a metonym for the city. AT: "I am continually thinking about your walls" or "I am always thinking about you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: your walls are continually before me

contextId.information: Yahweh speaks of the time when the people of Jerusalem were in exile as if the city was bereaved of her children. Those who were born while the people were in exile are spoken of as the city's children. AT: "Those who will inhabit you, who were born while the people were in exile" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: The children born during the time of your bereavement

contextId.information: Zion speaks of the people who are returning to inhabit the city as if those people were her children. Zion's question expresses her surprise that so many children now belong to her. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Who has borne these children for me?

contextId.information: Yahweh speaks of the people who will inhabit Jerusalem as if they were the city's children. He also speaks of the people of other nations helping the Israelites to return to Jerusalem as if they were carrying the Israelites. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: They will bring your sons in their arms and carry your daughters on their shoulders

contextId.information: Yahweh speaks of the people who will inhabit Zion as if they were the city's children. The terms "foster fathers" and "nursemaids" refer to men and women who become responsible for the care of children. AT: "The kings and queens of other nations will provide for your inhabitants" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Kings will be your foster fathers, and their queens your nursemaids

contextId.information: Possible meanings are 1) the oppressors will be so hungry that they will eat the flesh of their friends who have died. AT: "I will cause your oppressors to eat their own flesh" or 2) Yahweh speaks of the oppressors fighting against and destroying themselves as if they were eating themselves. AT: "I will cause your oppressors to destroy themselves, as if they were eating their own flesh" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I will feed your oppressors with their own flesh

contextId.information: Possible meanings are 1) the oppressors will be so thirsty that they drink the blood of their friends who have died. AT: "and they will drink their friends' blood and be like weak people who are drunk on wine" or 2) Yahweh speaks of the oppressors fighting against and destroying themselves as if they were drinking their own blood. AT: "and they will shed so much of their friends' blood that it will be as though they were getting drunk with wine" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: and they will get drunk on their own blood, as if it were wine

contextId.information: Yahweh speaks of drying up the rivers as if he were turning them into a desert. AT: "I make the rivers as dry as a desert" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I make the rivers a desert

contextId.information: These two phrases mean basically the same thing. Yahweh speaks of causing the sky to become dark as if he were clothing it with sackcloth. AT: "I make the sky dark, as if it were wearing dark sackcloth" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
contextId.quote: I clothe the sky with darkness; I cover it with sackcloth

contextId.information: Yahweh enabling his servant to hear and understand is spoken of as if Yahweh opened his ear. AT: "The Lord Yahweh has enabled me to hear and understand him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: The Lord Yahweh has opened my ear

contextId.information: This continues the metaphor from the previous verse of people who walk in darkness. Here people who try to live according to their own wisdom instead of trusting in Yahweh are spoken of as if they lit their own fires and carried about torches in order to see in the dark. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: all you who light fires ... flames that you have ignited

contextId.information: God speaks of saving people as if his salvation were a thing that could go out to them. AT: "I will save people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: my salvation will go out

contextId.information: Lifting the eyes represents looking at something above. AT: "Look up at the sky" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Lift up your eyes to the sky

contextId.information: Having God's law in the heart represents knowing God's law and wanting to obey it. AT: "who know and honor my law" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: who have my law in your heart

contextId.information: God speaks of people who abuse those who are righteous as if they were wool garments, and of their being destroyed as if insects ate them. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: For the moth will eat them up like a garment, and the worm will eat them like wool

contextId.information: Strength is spoken of as if it were some kind of clothing that people would wear to strengthen themselves in battle. AT: "make yourself strong" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: clothe yourself with strength

contextId.information: "who spread out the sky." This speaks of Yahweh having created the heavens as if he had stretched them out in the same way one would stretch out a large garment. AT: "who stretched out the heavens like a garment" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: who stretched out the heavens

contextId.information: This speaks of Yahweh causing the sea to move and the waves to rise and fall as if he were stirring the sea as one stirs the contents of a bowl with a large spoon. AT: "who causes the sea to churn" or "who makes the sea move up and down" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: who churns up the sea

contextId.information: This speaks of Yahweh telling Isaiah what to say as if his words were a physical object Yahweh had placed in Isaiah's mouth. AT: "I have told you what to say" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I have placed my words in your mouth

contextId.information: This speaks of the people acting drunk because they are suffering as if they have become drunk from being forced to drink the bowl of Yahweh's anger. AT: "you who are drunk from drinking the wine of the bowl of Yahweh's anger" or "you who act drunk, because you have suffered greatly" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: drunken one, but not drunk with wine

contextId.information: Yahweh speaks of having punished people as if he had forced them to drink from a bowl that was filled with his anger. See how you translated a similar phrase in [[:en:bible:notes:isa:51:17|51:17]]. AT: "the bowl which is filled with my anger" or "the cup which is filled with my anger" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: the bowl, which is the cup of my anger

contextId.information: This speaks of Yahweh punishing their enemies as if he were going to force them to drink from the cup filled with his anger. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I will put it into the hand of your tormentors

contextId.information: This word is repeated for emphasis and shows urgency. Isaiah trying to arouse the people is spoken of as if he were trying to wake them up from sleep. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Awake, awake

contextId.information: This refers to unclean people. A person who God considers spiritually unacceptable or defiled is spoken of as if the person were physically unclean. AT: "those who are not acceptable to God" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: the unclean

contextId.information: This speaks about Yahweh as if he were the owner of the people of Israel. Since he is the rightful owner he can give them away or take them back whenever he wants. This can be stated in active form. AT: "I sold you for nothing, and I will redeem you without money" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: You were sold for nothing, and you will be redeemed without money

contextId.information: Possible meanings are 1) "for nothing" means the Babylonians took the people unjustly and without cause or 2) this continues the metaphor from [[:en:bible:notes:isa:52:02|52:3]] where Yahweh is spoken of as if he owned the people of Israel and could give them away for nothing. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: for nothing

contextId.information: The servant causing the people of the nations to be acceptable to Yahweh is spoken of as if the servant were a priest who sprinkles the blood of a sacrifice to make someone or something acceptable to Yahweh. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: my servant will sprinkle many nations

contextId.information: "parched earth" is hard and dry ground that will not allow plants to grow and represents where the servant of Yahweh will come. AT: "out of an impossible situation" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: out of parched earth

contextId.information: To "bear" or carry an abstraction like sickness and sorrow represents taking it up. AT: "he has taken our sicknesses and sorrows upon himself" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: he has borne our sicknesses and carried our sorrows

contextId.information: Yahweh telling the people of Jerusalem to rejoice because there will be many people living in Jerusalem again is spoken of as if Yahweh were telling a barren women she is going to have many children. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: you barren woman ... children of the married woman

contextId.information: This continues the metaphor that began in [[:en:bible:notes:isa:54:01|54:1]]. Yahweh telling the people of Jerusalem to prepare because Yahweh will greatly increase their people is spoken of as if he is telling a woman to make her tent bigger to make room for many children. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Make your tent larger ... strengthen your stakes

contextId.information: Yahweh loving and taking care of his people is spoken of as if he were their husband. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: For your Maker is your husband

contextId.information: Yahweh sending his people away into exile then bringing them back is spoken of as if Yahweh were a husband who had rejected his wife but now accepts her. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: Yahweh has called you back as a wife ... like a woman married young and rejected

contextId.information: Yahweh being very angry is spoken of as if his anger were a flood that overwhelms people. AT: "When I was very angry" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: In a flood of anger

contextId.information: Listening to or paying attention to someone is spoken of as if it were turning one's ears to someone. AT: "Pay attention" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Turn your ears

contextId.information: This means eunuchs may have thought they could not be a part of God's people because they were deformed by castration (and for this reason could not have children). Israelites did not practice castration; foreigners did, sometimes for punishment. Eunuchs who had accepted the Hebrew faith knew that normally they were not allowed to worship in the temple (Deut. 23:1). The full meaning of this statement can be made clear. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: See, I am a dry tree

contextId.information: God is calling armies of other nations by comparing them to animals to come and attack the people of Israel. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: All you wild beasts of the field, come and devour, all you beasts in the forest

contextId.information: Yahweh continues comparing Israel's bad leaders to dogs. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: The dogs have big appetites

contextId.information: This is a strong insult against the people who practice sorcery because sorcery and magic includes idolatry. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: sons of the sorceress

contextId.information: "Water" represents all they need for an abundant life even when their surroundings do not have enough. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: satisfy you in regions where there is no water

contextId.information: This refers to God exalting the nation in reputation and power in response to living righteously. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I will make you ride on the heights of the earth

contextId.information: Eggs of a poisonous snake hatch into more dangerous snakes. "Poisonous snakes" represents evil the people do that harms more and more. AT: "They make evil that spreads out to make more evil" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: They hatch eggs of a poisonous snake

contextId.information: This means their sinful deeds cannot be covered and hidden, just as a web cannot serve as clothing and cover someone. AT: "Their evil deeds will be exposed as useless" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Their webs cannot be used for garments, nor can they cover themselves with their works

contextId.information: "paths" represents their way of life. AT: "they never do what is just" or "everything they do is unjust" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: there is no justice in their paths

contextId.information: This refers to the glorious things Yahweh has done for the inhabitants of Jerusalem. They are now to show that glory through what they do and say and have hope in the future. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Arise, shine; for your light has come, and the glory of Yahweh has risen on you

contextId.information: This refers to the wealth and plenty that will be drained from foreign nations. Both clauses repeat the same idea for emphasis. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
contextId.quote: You will also drink the milk of the nations, and will nurse at the breast of kings

contextId.information: The moon will not literally disappear. This is saying that in comparison to the light of Yahweh, the light of the sun and the moon will be nothing. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])
contextId.quote: Your sun will no longer set, nor will your moon withdraw and disappear

contextId.information: This means Yahweh has caused the people to be strong and sturdy. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: oaks of righteousness, the planting of Yahweh

contextId.information: This means Yahweh will love the people of Israel and will always be with them as is a husband. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: and your land will be married

contextId.information: This refers to prophets, officials, or possibly angels, who are constantly praying for the people of Jerusalem like watchmen who constantly guard the city. See how you translated "watchmen" in [[:en:bible:notes:isa:52:07|52:8]] and [[:en:bible:notes:isa:56:09|56:10]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: watchmen on your walls

contextId.information: The places on the earth that are very far away are spoken of as if they were the places where the earth ends. This phrase also forms a merism and refers to everywhere in between the ends. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:isa:40:27|40:28]]. AT "the farthest places of the earth" or "the entire earth" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_merism]])
contextId.quote: the ends of the earth

contextId.information: Here "I" refers to Yahweh. This imagery refers to Yahweh destroying his enemies. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I have trodden grapes

contextId.information: This means Yahweh made them stunned and senseless by his full wrath and punishment. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: and made them drunk in my wrath

contextId.information: This refers to when God protected and saved the people of Israel from the Egyptians many years earlier. The full meaning of this statement can be made clear. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: he lifted them up and carried them

contextId.information: This means to become resistant to Yahweh's teaching by refusing to listen and obey. Here "heart" represents their motives, feelings and desires. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: harden our hearts

contextId.information: Yahweh compares the people of Israel to a cluster of grapes that still has some good juice in it. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: As when juice is found in a cluster of grapes

contextId.information: Yahweh's appearances in the Old Testament are often accompanied by fire that represents Yahweh's anger and judgment. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: coming with fire
